addressleaf.section:
20 Sep
t
1590
M
r
Bodeley to my L. from
e
Haghe
.

page.lettertext:
fol.61r
May it please yo
r
good L. to advertise her
Hig
nes
that according to
e motion of her letters
of
e 10 of this moneth, whiche I have delive-
red to the
General states
, the sending of forces
into
e Enemies contrey, hath bin put in con-
sultation, aswell in their assembly, as in
e
Councel of state
. And for the reasons alleaged
in her Hig
nes
letters, whiche I accompaned, as
I was willed, w
t
some other considerations, it is
fully resolved, that
e chiefest of their forces
shall goe presently for
Brabant
,
if
Count Mau
-
resol
u
to have
e for
c
sent into
brabant
rice, and other principall persons about him
whiche are nowe at
e siege of Hemart and
Heele
, shall
thinke it expedient
. To this
effect they have written to Count Maurice, and
I have also sent him her Ma
ties
letter. It
was in deliberation among them, to send their
forces
into
Flanders
: but they finde it full of
to send into fl
a
d
full of d
a
ger
danger and difficultie, for many respectes,
a place for desc
e
t
tr
a
s
p
of horss &
artillary
especially for
want of a commodious descent
,
for their forces, a
safe retrait
, and a conve-
nient meanes to transport
their horse, and
great artillerie
: whiche will also be subject
to excessive charges, and may ill be spared at
this present. For I can say uppon knowledge,
that they have bin forced to disbourse extraor-
dinarely, above a hundred thousand florins,
in their late exploit before
Nieumeghen
.
Upon returne of answear from Count Maurice
I thinke
e states themselves will certifie her
fol.61v
Hig
nes
howe they purpose to imploy their force
against the Enemie. Two daies
past I receaved yo
r
L. letter of the 7 of this
moneth, by old
M
r
Allen
. Uppon the q
e
stions
there proposed about
e enterprise of
Dunkerke
D
u
kyrk
I have conferred w
t
e party, that made
e
ouverture unto me: whose particular answears,
together w
t
e questions, I have written a part,
and send yo
r
L. heere inclosed.
Moreover unto that, w
ch
her Ma
tie
doth demaunde,
whether this practise uppon Dunkerke may be well
effected, by suche other newe forces, as her Hig
nes
may send in to some part of Flanders: it is
answeared by the partie, that if it be meant
by
Ostend
, the site of that place is not
e best
ost
e
d not [met]
for that purpose: because it is too long a marche
9 leag
bet
w
ost
e
d & d
u
kyrk
from thens to
Dunkerke
by land, being 9 leagues:
and by water they can not come fourth
but
w
t
speciall windes. W
t
all it is to be feared,
at
the sending of newe forces into those quarters
w
t
out a very great likelihood in
e Enemies
opinion, that they are to be imploied in some
other special action, will move
e neighbour
townes to a great suspic
o
n, and make them so
carefull in providing for
e worst, as they
will hardly be entrapped. In w
ch
regard
he thought that
e embarking of men
at
Dover
,
at Dover
would be nothing so subject to suche inconvenience,
as on this side
e seas.
fol.62r
Rainold Peterson
of
Horne
, is nowe in Horne:
from whens I will ether send for him hither,
or procure his answear to
e questions, that are
moved by yo
r
L. Howbeit I founde him very
rawly instructed, for mater of special circum-
stance: and as farre as I remember he told
me expressely, that he himself never sawe
Pedro
van Arragon
.
S
r
Edward Norreis
hath bin lately at
e Hage, and as her Ma
tie
req
e
sted
by her letters to
e states, and my
LL.
at home
directed me heere to deale w
t
e
Councell
, he was
admitted to
e government of
e towne of Ostend,
S
r
Edward Norris
ad
m
Governo
r
of ost
e
d
w
t
a general good liking, aswell of
e states, as
of
e Councel. And for his intertenment they
have assigned him monethly 40
li
sterling, to be
xl
li
sterl
y
g
[
mese]
raised uppon
e contributions of Flanders, w
ch
I
stand in great doubt, will hardly amount to
pay that allowance. Because I was requested
by my LL. of
e Councel, to further this Election
of S
r
Edward Norreis, I beseeche yo
r
L. if they
knowe it not already, to signifie unto them,
what is done in his cause. I have
no answear as yet from
e General states
to o
r
last Propositions: nor I see no hast
at
is made. Still they doe pretend, that they
knowe not as yet
e pleasure of their
pleasure
Principals. But if it be so, as I am informed,
when their pleasure is knowen, it will hardly
deserve this lingering attendance. For I am
told by my frindes, that there is an answear
made by these men heere, by way of a project,
20
7br
fol.62v
and sent unto
e Provinces to be made autenticall.
Whiche, if it be true, is an unusual proceeding,
a disordred
m
a
ner
and wholy heere disliked of indifferent persons,
who can not be persuaded, that they will frame
any answear to her Hig
nes
content.
To signifie to yo
r
L. what hath passed heere of
late, in
e exploits of these contreis, About
e
end
of Au
g
last,
S
r
Francis Vere
was appointed
ult
o
Au
g
by
e Councel of state, w
t
600 footmen
and
6
cornet of horse, to disasiege
e house of
Lutteke-
luttekehove to
be rescued
hove, a strong fort situat between
Werden
and
Essen
,
in
e territorie of
Rekelinghusen
,
in
e Diocese of
Collen
,
whiche was lately sur-
prised by a Scottishe captain of these contreis,
a s
c
cap
t
and presently uppon it besieged by
e Enemie.
The third of this moneth S
r
Francis came
before it: where he found that
e Enemie had
fortified before
e entrie of
e house. Uppon
his arrival
300 of
e Enemies, assigned for
the gard of their trenches, retired to
e fort,
and refusing to yeld, being sommoned, were
assaulted so valiantly, that after half an
houres fight at hand blowes, o
r
souldiers en-
tred
e fort, and put all to
e sworde. Wher-
e fort won
all
e enemys
to
e sword
uppon
e house was relieved, and besides some
other small fortes thereabout yelded presently
of them selves. There were only slaine
in
e conflict, of S
r
Francis troupes 25 and
25 sla
y
40 hurt
13
7ber
some 40 hurt.
Thirten daies after, retur
-
ning towardes
Disbourgh
,
he assaulted the fort
fol.63r
of
Graef by
Wesel
, a place of importance in
Graef by
Wesel
the Enemies possession: where they yelded unto
him after
two assaultes
, and departed with
2 assalt
bagge and baggage. To report a truth unto
yo
r
L.
S
r
Francis Vere by
his special industrie
and vertu, doth force this people to
[.]
love
and commend him: wheras otherwise, their
ingratitude is so strange, that they shewe very
seeldome, at
e best endevo
rs
of any of o
r
na-
tion, any Loving contentment. While S
r
Francis is busied in those quarters, it was
resolved heere at home, that
e houses of He-
mart and Heele should be beaten w
t
e Canon,
and assaulted, at one instant bothe together.
he
m
art
heale
For whiche cause they have revoked S
r
Francis
and have assigned him, and as many compa-
nies more, as may amount to
e nomber of
4000
to meete w
t
Count Maurice at
Gor-
chum
,
or
Bommel
,
where they are at this pre-
sent in hand w
t
their enterprise, and have
battered
e fort of
Hemart
for two daies toge-
ther. But I can not yet understand, that S
r
Francis is come thither. The
Germaine Ambassado
rs
, of whome I have writ-
Germ
a
a
bassa
d
ten in a former letter, are newly departed
towardes
Frankford
: where they meete in a
diet, with
e Deputies of other Princes, to make
a publike relation of their answear from hens.
Wherof the effect is no other, but that they are
contented heere, to deliver up the fortes of
Lutte-
kehove
fol.63v
and
Budricke,
over against
Graeff afore
men-
Budryck Graeff
tioned, w
ch
were all suche places, as were lately
taken from
e Enemie. But for
Sgraven wert
sgrav
e
wert
Skinkes
fort
, because
e
states of Guelders
pretend
a proprietie and right to
e place, they require
that there may be a meeting of Deputies on bothe
sides, to conferre uppon
e reasons that wilbe
alleaged by those of Guelders. This answear
was reputed by
e Ambassado
rs
to be but frivolous
and dilatorie. Nevertheles, suche as it was,
they could not obtene it, untill they shewed
openly their great dislike to be trained on
so long, and prepared theruppon to returne
w
t
out an answear: threatning them w
t
all,
w
t
e publike proscription and band of the
Empire. Here is present
newes from
e Count, that
e house of
Hemart, ha-
ving endured above 1200 canon shotte, is come
Hamart dely-
vered by C
o
po
s
to composition, and
e souldiers in it have quited
e place. So that nowe there whole strength is
imploied against Heele. There is also
freshe advertisment from S
r
Francis Vere, who re-
maineth as yet in
e land of
Cleve
, that with
some further succor from hens, he is in hope to
recover
Berke,
e fort of
Rees
,
e
Beeke, and
other places confining. By letters out of
Brabant
it is certified, that
Count Mansfeld
doth assemble all
e forces, that his garrisons
can spare. These advertisments have
putt both
e states heere, and
e Councel of state
in suche a perplexitie, as they can not determine
fol.64r
whether it will steede
e contrey more, to pursue
the victorie w
t
S
r
Francis Vere: or rather upon
this benefit of having Hemart, to attempt somw
at
upon
Bolduke
,
e fort of
Terheide
by
Breda
, and
e Enemies holdes in those quarters: or els to goe
forward w
t
their former deseigne, for making in-
cursions into Brabant: w
ch
they are persuaded
will prove unprofitable, if Count Mansfeld be
bent to encounter their forces. What is like to
be resolved, I can not conjecture: but I will
certifie yo
r
L. assoone as any thing is offered.
And so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. 21 Sep
t
1590.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
